World Health Organization 7 million premature deaths annually linked to air pollution
The World Health Organization was established in 1948 and is now the leading internation source of public health information.
This particular piece by the WHO is valuable to many as it is an update to a previous, popular study on the health effects associated with air pollution.
While this article remains broad in the exact location of its studies, it uses advanced technological tools such as satellite data, ground-level monitoring measurements and data on pollution emissions from key sources to get pinpoint the dispersion of airborne pollutants.
This update to a study conducted in 2012 on the relationship between air pollutants and various diseases shows that the current situation is worse than previously thought. In particular, this study outlines how the most voulnerable groups to air pollution, children and the elderly, are the most exposed to it due to their more stagnant lifestyle.
While the statistics in this study generally speak for themselves, it is worth pointing out that the sources of the pollutants do not effect all people equally. For this reason, it is important to understand the actual externality dispersion so that our portions of the burden are put into perspective.
There are many application of this article. However, first and foremost, it is to be used to set the groundwork for any arguement regarding public health as it related to air pollution. No arguement can be formed without first establishing the concrete relationship between airbourne pollutants and public health issues.
The fact that this artice represents an update to a study shoould only provide more reader confidence in the World Health Organization. Although he origional statement made in 2012 had to be updated, the fact that they are on an ever expanding search for information makes their input paramount to any legitimate claim on the current state of worldwide air quality.
